content.notes: Content not refactored in Phase 1; original preserved under payload.

points_of_interest.name: Nile River
points_of_interest.description_original: Africa's longest river. Historically considered the world's longest river, but some research points to the Amazon being longer. The Nile is vitally important to trade, agriculture, and fishing.
points_of_interest.description: Africa’s longest river, the Nile, has been a lifeline since ancient times. Its waters feed crops and people, carry boats, and helped civilizations rise along its banks.

points_of_interest.name: Ngorongoro Crater
points_of_interest.description_original: The world's largest inactive vocanic caldera. The crater formed when a massive volcano exploded and collapsed on itself. The crater is up to 2000 feet deep and covers nearly 100 square miles.
points_of_interest.description: Ngorongoro Crater is the world’s largest inactive volcanic bowl. Long ago, a giant volcano exploded and collapsed inward, leaving a crater nearly 2,000 feet deep and about 100 square miles wide.

points_of_interest.name: Okavango Delta
points_of_interest.description_original: An inland wetland home to hundreds of species of plants and animals. Uniquely, the Okavango begins flooding during the dry season of the surrounding Kalahari. This brings animals from around the Kalahari to graze and hunt.
points_of_interest.description: The Okavango Delta is a vast swamp oasis teeming with life. Unusually, its waters flood during the Kalahari’s dry season, turning desert into temporary wetlands. This surprise flood draws animals to graze and hunt.

points_of_interest.name: Sahara Desert
points_of_interest.description_original: The largest hot desert in the world. This massive desert spans most of North Africa. The weather is sunny over 90% of the time in most of the desert and the average temperature in the hottest months easily exceeds 100 degrees Farenheit.
points_of_interest.description: The Sahara is the world’s largest hot desert, an ocean of sand across North Africa. It’s sunny here nearly all the time – over 90% of daylight hours! In the blistering summer, average daytime temperatures soar above 100°F (38°C).

points_of_interest.name: Mt. Kilimanjaro
points_of_interest.description_original: A dormant volcano and Africa's tallest mountain.The mountain and the surrounding park are popular with hikers and wildlife lovers. Kilimanjaro's ice cap is heavily studied by scientists because it is melting quickly.
points_of_interest.description: Mount Kilimanjaro is a sleeping volcano and Africa’s tallest peak. Hikers and wildlife lovers flock to its forested slopes. Even its shrinking ice cap fascinates scientists studying how fast it’s melting.

points_of_interest.name: Great Rift Valley
points_of_interest.description_original: A massive and complex series of rifts formed by tectonic plates ripping the crust of East Africa apart. The Great Rift Valley forms expansive and scenic views from Ethiopia to Mozambique.
points_of_interest.description: The Great Rift Valley is a huge scar across East Africa, created as tectonic plates slowly pull the land apart. This giant valley spans from Ethiopia to Mozambique, offering breathtaking views.

points_of_interest.name: Victoria Falls
points_of_interest.description_original: In local languages, Victoria Falls is named "The smoke that thunders" and "Boiling Water". This waterfall on the Zambezi is one of the largest waterfalls on Earth.
points_of_interest.description: Victoria Falls is so grand, locals call it “The Smoke that Thunders.” This roaring Zambezi River waterfall is one of the largest in the world.

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.
Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.

Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). If you need a complete capitals list or a capital/non-capital flag for every major city, add that as a separate data layer.

posters.title: Africa Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: Mount Everest
points_of_interest.description_original: The world's tallest mountiain. Its summit dots the border between China and Nepal. It's peak attracts many climbers every year.
points_of_interest.description: Mount Everest, on the border of Nepal and China, is the tallest mountain in the world and draws many climbers.

points_of_interest.name: Flaming Cliffs Gobi Desert
points_of_interest.description_original: These beautiful fiery red cliffs are where some of the best dinosaur fossils have been found and where the first dinosaur eggs were found.
points_of_interest.description: Mongolia’s Flaming Cliffs glow fiery red in the Gobi Desert, and have yielded the world’s first dinosaur eggs and many excellent dinosaur fossils.

points_of_interest.name: Mount Fuji
points_of_interest.description_original: This iconic volcano is a popular symbol of Japan. It is a popular destination for hikers, climbers, and other tourists from around the world.
points_of_interest.description: Mount Fuji is an iconic volcano and a symbol of Japan. Its graceful peak draws hikers, climbers, and tourists from around the world.

points_of_interest.name: Valley of the Geysers
points_of_interest.description_original: Much of Siberia is unexplored. This valley, that has the second highest concentration of geysers on Earth, was only discovered in 1941.
points_of_interest.description: The Valley of the Geysers in Siberia has the world’s second-highest concentration of geysers and was only discovered in 1941.

points_of_interest.name: Can Gio Mangrove Forest
points_of_interest.description_original: The Can Gio wetlands support not only thousands of mangroves, but also around 200 different species of wildlife and 150 species of flora.
points_of_interest.description: Vietnam’s Cần Giờ Mangrove Forest is rich with life—thousands of mangrove trees, plus about 200 species of animals and 150 species of plants.

points_of_interest.name: Valley of the Flowers
points_of_interest.description_original: This valley is one of the most picturesque flowery fields in the world and blooms between August and September.
points_of_interest.description: In India, the Valley of Flowers is a beautiful meadow that bursts into bloom each August and September.

points_of_interest.name: Gokyo Cho Lake
points_of_interest.description_original: The main lake of the Gokyo lakes system, this glacier fed lake holds religious significance to both Hindus and Buddhists.
points_of_interest.description: Gokyo Cho, the largest of Nepal’s Gokyo Lakes, is a glacier-fed lake that is sacred to both Hindus and Buddhists.

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.

posters.title: Asia Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: The Matterhorn
points_of_interest.description_original: Dominating the Alps range, the Matterhorn is thought to be around 50 million years old.
points_of_interest.description: The Matterhorn, an iconic spire of the Alps, is roughly 50 million years old.

points_of_interest.name: The Black Forest
points_of_interest.description_original: This densely wooded mountain range is situated along the Rhine River. With dozens of lakes, stunning scenery and a number of historic towns, it’s one of the most relaxing and naturally beautiful places in Germany.
points_of_interest.description: The Black Forest is a dense mountain woodland along Germany’s Rhine River. It’s dotted with lakes and historic towns. This peaceful region is famous for inspiring fairy tales.

points_of_interest.name: Giant's Causeway
points_of_interest.description_original: The Giant’s Causeway is a bizarre yet fascinating natural phenomenon. It is comprised of three modestly-sized fingers of naturally created paving. Thousands of basalt columns formed as  lava cooled and contracted, fracturing with mysterious regularity to create what looks like a fiendishly complicated giant keyboard – though according to folklore, the causeway is what’s left of a bridge to Scotland built by the giant, Finn McCool.
points_of_interest.description: Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland is a bizarre landscape of thousands of hexagonal basalt columns. These stone pillars formed long ago as cooling lava cracked into a honeycomb pattern. According to legend, an Irish giant built this “causeway” as a bridge to Scotland.

points_of_interest.name: Preikestolen
points_of_interest.description_original: The thrill of the vertical drop is palpable at Preikestolen, or "Pulpit Rock," a narrow plateau towering nearly 2,000 feet above a fjord in the south of Norway.
points_of_interest.description: Preikestolen (“Pulpit Rock”) in Norway is a narrow cliff-top ledge almost 2,000 feet high. Visitors feel a thrill standing at the edge and peering down at the fjord.

points_of_interest.name: Verdon Gorge
points_of_interest.description_original: Sometimes called the "Grand Canyon of France",  this gorge has been shaped by oceans and rivers for nearly 250 million years.
points_of_interest.description: Verdon Gorge—often called France’s Grand Canyon—was carved by water over 250 million years. Ancient seas and later rivers etched this valley.

points_of_interest.name: White Nights
points_of_interest.description_original: In the summer, days get longer. Above 60 degrees in latitude, the sun barely sets creating a perpetual twilight. These white nights are celebrated in the summer, especially in Russia.
points_of_interest.description: In summer at high latitudes (above 60° N), the sun barely sets. This creates “white nights” of endless twilight. Many northern regions—especially Russia—celebrate these magical bright nights each year.

points_of_interest.name: Ice Caves of Iceland
points_of_interest.description_original: Instead of walking on a glacier, visitors to the Vatnajokull Glacier Ice Caves in Iceland can walk in luminous caves embedded in the glacier.
points_of_interest.description: In Iceland’s Vatnajökull Glacier, visitors explore dazzling blue caves inside the ice. It’s like walking through frozen tunnels of light beneath the glacier.

points_of_interest.name: Northern Lights
points_of_interest.description_original: The sun releases highly charged particles that move through space. When those particles hit the Earth's atmosphere, the collisions cause bright dancing aurorae around Earth's magnetic poles.
points_of_interest.description: Charged particles from the Sun crash into Earth’s upper atmosphere near the poles, making the sky glow with the dancing colors of the aurora (the Northern Lights).

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.
Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.

Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). If you need a complete capitals list or a capital/non-capital flag for every major city, add that as a separate data layer.

posters.title: Europe Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: Grand Canyon
points_of_interest.description_original: At up to a mile deep, up to 18 miles wide, and 277 miles long, the Grand Canyon cuts through the Arizona desert revealing rock that is billions of years old.
points_of_interest.description: The Grand Canyon, up to a mile deep, 18 miles wide, and 277 miles long, slices through Arizona’s desert. Its cliffs show rock layers that are billions of years old.

points_of_interest.name: Mississippi River
points_of_interest.description_original: The fourth longest river in the world, this huge river and its tributaries drain 31 States. The river system is important both for agriculture and for supplying drinking water to millions of people
points_of_interest.description: The Mississippi River is the fourth-longest river in the world. This mighty waterway and its many branches drain 31 U.S. states, watering farms and providing drinking water to millions.

points_of_interest.name: El Yunque Rainforest
points_of_interest.description_original: Home to thousands of plant and hundreds of animal species, El Yunque has massive biodiversity in only 28,000 acres.
points_of_interest.description: El Yunque Rainforest is small—only 28,000 acres—but it’s bursting with life, sheltering thousands of plants and hundreds of animals.

points_of_interest.name: Arenal Volcano
points_of_interest.description_original: At 7500 years old, Arenal is a really young volcano compared most others. At over 5300 feet high, it soars over the surrounding tropical forest.
points_of_interest.description: Arenal Volcano is young—only about 7,500 years old. It rises more than 5,300 feet above the tropical forest, looming large over the green landscape.

points_of_interest.name: Rosario Sanctuary, Michoacán
points_of_interest.description_original: Each year millions of Monarch butterflies make their way to the Rosario Sanctuary in Michoacán, their final resting place after their long migration from the north.
points_of_interest.description: Every year, millions of monarch butterflies migrate south to the Rosario Sanctuary in Michoacán, Mexico, where they finally settle and rest after their long journey.

points_of_interest.name: Basaltic Prisms, Hidalgo
points_of_interest.description_original: The basaltic prisms of Hidalgo are geometrically shaped columns of basalt rock between thirty and fifty meters high created by ancient lava flows.
points_of_interest.description: The Basaltic Prisms of Hidalgo are hexagon-shaped rock columns, 30–50 m tall, created when ancient lava cooled and cracked into geometric pillars.

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.

posters.title: North America Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: Amazon Rainforest
points_of_interest.description_original: Spanning 9 countries, the Amazon Rainforest is the largest rainforest on the planet and home to thousands of species of plants and animals.
points_of_interest.description: Spanning 9 countries, the Amazon is Earth’s largest rainforest, teeming with thousands of plant and animal species.

points_of_interest.name: Galapagos Islands
points_of_interest.description_original: This archipelago 600 miles off the coast of Ecuador is famous for its high number of endemic species and its influence on Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection.
points_of_interest.description: The Galápagos Islands, ~600 miles off Ecuador’s coast, are famous for unique creatures found nowhere else. Observations here helped Charles Darwin develop his theory of evolution.

points_of_interest.name: Lake Titicaca
points_of_interest.description_original: The highest navigible lake, Lake Titicaca is also the largest lake in South America. It's numerous islands are home to several unique cultures.
points_of_interest.description: Lake Titicaca is the world’s highest navigable lake and the largest in South America. Its many islands are home to unique cultures.

points_of_interest.name: Atacama Desert
points_of_interest.description_original: The driest non-polar desert in the world features volcanoes, geysers, hot springs, and jagged hills that look like an alien planet. A lot of films and TV series use the Atacama as a stand-in for Mars.
points_of_interest.description: The Atacama Desert is the driest place on Earth outside the poles. Its landscape of volcanoes, geysers, hot springs, and jagged hills looks so otherworldly that movies often film here to mimic Mars.

points_of_interest.name: Torres del Paine
points_of_interest.description_original: A breathtaking national park famous for its jagged mountains surrounded by rivers, glaciers, and lakes.
points_of_interest.description: Torres del Paine is famous for jagged mountain peaks ringed by rivers, glaciers, and lakes.

points_of_interest.name: Uyuni Salt Flats
points_of_interest.description_original: The Uyuni Salt flats span nearly 4100 square miles, and are so flat that their elevation only varies by less than a meter. The salty crust is up several meters deep in some places. Also, these salt flats are home to over half of the Earth's known lithium reserves.
points_of_interest.description: Bolivia’s Uyuni Salt Flats cover nearly 4,100 square miles. They are so flat that their height varies by less than a meter across the whole area. In some places the salt crust is several meters thick. Amazingly, over half of Earth’s known lithium lies beneath these flats.

points_of_interest.name: Perito Moreno Glacier
points_of_interest.description_original: Located in the the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, which is the third largest reserve of fresh water. Perito Moreno is unusual among glaciers in that it so far has not been shrinking due to rising global temperatures.
points_of_interest.description: Perito Moreno Glacier in Argentina sits in the Southern Patagonian Ice Field—the world’s third-largest reserve of fresh water. Unlike most glaciers, this one hasn’t been shrinking despite rising global temperatures.

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.
Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.

capitals_supplement.name: Sucre
capitals_supplement.capital_update_note: Bolivia has two capitals: Sucre (constitutional/judicial) and La Paz (administrative).

posters.title: South America Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: Great Barrier Reef
points_of_interest.description_original: The only living thing visible from outer space, the Great Barrier reef spans for thousands of miles and is millions of years old.
points_of_interest.description: Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is the only living structure visible from space, spanning thousands of miles and growing over millions of years.

points_of_interest.name: Uluru
points_of_interest.description_original: An isolated sandstone monolith that's as captivating as it is imposing, Uluru is a sacred place to the local Anangu people.
points_of_interest.description: Uluru is a giant sandstone rock standing alone in Australia’s desert. It’s both awe-inspiring and sacred to the local Anangu people.

points_of_interest.name: Mt. Wilhelm
points_of_interest.description_original: Mount Wilhelm reaches a summit of 14,793 feet, making it the highest mountain in Oceania.
points_of_interest.description: Mount Wilhelm is 14,793 feet tall, the highest peak in Oceania.

points_of_interest.name: Daintree Forest
points_of_interest.description_original: The Daintree Rainforest is a tropical rainforest which covers an area of 460 square miles creating the largest continuous rainforest within the continent.
points_of_interest.description: Australia’s Daintree Rainforest spans about 460 square miles and is the continent’s largest continuous rainforest—a green haven of ancient trees and diverse wildlife.

points_of_interest.name: Togari Natural Arch
points_of_interest.description_original: Togari Rock is an island with a massive natural rock arch. Natural arches form through years of weathering processes.
points_of_interest.description: Togari Rock is a small island with a huge natural arch formed by years of wind and waves.

points_of_interest.name: Bora Bora Lagoon
points_of_interest.description_original: Widely considered one of the world's most beautiful lagoons, Bora Bora's lagoon is a popular international tourist destination.
points_of_interest.description: Bora Bora’s lagoon is famous for its clear blue water and coral reefs, making it a dream getaway.

points_of_interest.name: Milford Sound
points_of_interest.description_original: Milford Sound is the leading natural attraction within the country of New Zealand. The sound runs 9.3 miles inland from the Tasman Sea. The mouth of the fjord is engulfed by rock faces that tower into the sky of the fjord reaching height of 3,900 feet.
points_of_interest.description: Milford Sound is New Zealand’s most famous natural attraction—a majestic fjord stretching about 9 miles inland from the Tasman Sea. At its entrance, sheer rock cliffs soar ~3,900 feet high, framing the dark waters below.

notes: Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.

Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). If you need a complete capitals list or a capital/non-capital flag for every major city, add that as a separate data layer.

capitals_supplement.name: Yaren District
capitals_supplement.capital_update_note: Nauru has no official capital; government offices are in Yaren, treated as the capital for international reporting.

posters.title: Oceania Cities & Points of Interest
posters.subtitle: Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)

points_of_interest.name: Mount Erebus
points_of_interest.description_original: This large Antarctic volcano has erupted continuously since 1841.
points_of_interest.description: Earth’s southernmost fire-mountain, glowing nonstop since 1841.

points_of_interest.name: Airdevronsix Icefall
points_of_interest.description_original: Named for U.S. Navy Air Development Squadron Six, these icefalls are larger than any waterfall on Earth. The East Antarctic Ice sheet pours from the hills above into the dry valleys below.
points_of_interest.description: Ice cliffs named after Navy Squadron Six spill a white waterfall of glacier into the bone-dry McMurdo Valleys.

points_of_interest.name: Blood Falls
points_of_interest.description_original: The reddish orange color of this waterfall comes from iron trapped underneath the glacier. Iron that is slowly being eaten by rare bacteria.
points_of_interest.description: Rust-red water oozes from Taylor Glacier, iron-rich and bacteria-fed, painting the ice like a frozen lava flow.

points_of_interest.name: Katabatic Winds
points_of_interest.description_original: Hot air rises. But the katabatic winds are so cold and dense that they can move down glaciers at near hurricane speed.
points_of_interest.description: Super-cold, heavy air races downhill at near-hurricane speeds—a gravity-powered chill sweeping Antarctica’s glaciers clean.

points_of_interest.name: Lake Vanda
points_of_interest.description_original: The water in Lake Vanda is 10 times saltier than sea water. It's even saltier than the Dead Sea.
points_of_interest.description: Ten-times saltier than seawater, Lake Vanda stays liquid under ice, stacking warm layers like a natural solar pool.

points_of_interest.name: Cape Renard
points_of_interest.description_original: Known for the distinct rock outcroppings known as the Una Peaks, Cape Renard was discovered in 1898.
points_of_interest.description: Jagged Una Peaks spear skyward at Cape Renard, an 1898 discovery guiding ships through Antarctic fjords.

points_of_interest.name: Deception Island
points_of_interest.description_original: Part of the South Shetland Islands, Deception Island is the exposed part of an active shield volcano with a diameter of 30 km.
points_of_interest.description: Sail into a hidden volcano: Deception Island’s caldera harbor steams with geothermal beaches amid South Shetland’s icy seas.

points_of_interest.name: Lake Untersee
points_of_interest.description_original: This permanently frozen freshwater lake has a pH that peaks at 12.1. Unique microorganisms and certain sediments keep the pH high, supersaturate the lake with oxygen, and produce extreme amounts of methane.
points_of_interest.description: Sealed beneath ice lids, Lake Untersee brews “alien” life—ultra-alkaline, oxygen-rich waters where microbes belch methane bubbles like champagne.
